acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Not classified from 96 hours LC50=484mg/L of the fish (Fathead Minnows) (HSDB, 2004).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 162mg/kg (IARC 79 (2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 2B by IARC (2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was not water-insolubility (the water-solubility =1110mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), and acute toxicity was low, it was classified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and positive data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in IARC 79 (2001) and NTP DB (Access on May 2006).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of cleft palate and abnormal behaviour of the offspring observed in teratogenicity studies with mice and rats, described in IARC 79 (2001) (though no data are available regarding parental toxicity).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, thyroid)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence: "Sedation is the most common side effect of exposure to phenobarbital in humans. Overdosage of phenobarbital leads to nystagmus and ataxia," "In the patient, T4 level was decreased whereas T3 and TSH responses to thyrotropin-releasing hormone were within the normal range" (IARC 79 (2003)), "A 2-yr-old child developed massive hepatic necrosis caused by an unusual hypersensitivity response to phenobarbital that was prescribed for presumed febrile seizures," "phenobarbital induced a hypersensitivity state consisting of tubulointerstitial nephritis, exfoliative dermatitis and hepatitis" (HSDB (2002)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "the liver of the test animal showed an occurrence of moderate to severe hypertrophy of centrolobular hepatocytes," "serum T4 and T3 levels were decreased, whereas TSH production was increased," "mild to moderate follicular hypertrophy of the thyroid gland and moderate hepatocellular hypertrophy occurred" (IARC 79 (2003)). 
The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2. Since the priority rating of the study reporting the effects on the liver and kidneys in humans is 2, these effects are classified into Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "somnolence" (RTECS (2006)).
